subject: Gardening
title: Light-Sensitive Seeds
description: A quick, practical guide to Light-Sensitive Seeds.

hook.text: Lettuce seeds need light to germinate. Bury them too deep and they'll never sproutâ€”even in perfect soil.

buildup.text: Photoblastic seeds detect light through phytochrome proteins. Red light promotes germination; far-red light inhibits it.

discovery.text: This system tells the seed how deep it is. Red light penetrates only a few millimetersâ€”deeper burial means darkness.

twist.text: Under leaf canopy, far-red light dominates. Seeds detect this and refuse to sprout where they'd be shaded out.

climax.text: Seeds use light as a depth gauge and competition sensorâ€”remarkably sophisticated for a structure with no brain.

punchline.text: Seeds can sense if they're buried too deep using light.

quiz.question: Why does far-red light inhibit seed germination?
options: Far-red light damages the embryo's developing cells
It signals that established plants are overhead, where the seedling would be shaded out
Far-red wavelengths destroy the endosperm's stored nutrients
